key_title: Key to the species of Abutilon

source.author: Barker, R.M.
source.title: Abutilon
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Barker, R.M. (1996). Abutilon. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Flowers yellowish to orange with darker veins, pendulous; staminal column usually longer than petals; leaves palmately 3–5-lobed, glabrous above with scattered stellate hairs below
Flowers yellow, rarely orange, held erect or spreading; staminal column contained within petals; leaves not or hardly divided, both surfaces pubescent
Fruitlets more than 10, remaining attached basally or soon dissociating; plants upright or sprawling; leaves ovate to broadly ovate, never subsagittate at base
Fruitlets 5–8, remaining attached basally; plants prostrate with leaves broadly ovate and sometimes 3–5-lobed, or erect twiggy herbs with narrowly ovate leaves with subsagittate bases
Adjacent mericarps adhering to each other for over three-quarters of their length; garden-escaped exotic species
Adjacent mericarps adhering for less than half their length; native species of northern Victoria
Mericarps distinctly awned, awns >2 mm long; staminal column glabrous
Mericarps not or hardly awned; staminal column stellate-pubescent; apparently no longer extant in Victoria
Erect shrubs; mericarps distinctly exceeding calyx; leaves up to 18 cm long
Plants spreading or sprawling; mericarps shorter than or subequal to calyx lobes; leaves less than 8 cm long
Calyx-lobes not keeled at base but with darker midline at apex of each lobe, not enclosing fruit; calyx campanulate in open flower; mericarps rounded at point of basal attachment to columella
Calyx-lobes distinctly keeled at base, without darker midline at apex of each lobe, enclosing fruit; calyx urceolate in open flower; mericarps notched at point of basal attachment to columella
Plants prostrate, 30–70 cm wide; leaves broadly ovate, to 3 cm long and wide, cordate and rounded at base, 3–5-lobed or not lobed; clayey floodplain soils in the north-west
Plants erect, spindly, to 100 cm high; leaves narrowly ovate, to 4 cm long, 1 cm wide, subsagittate at base; rain-shadow areas of the east
